PostValue.explanation: This is a useful, time-sensitive opportunity announcement for people working on food-system interventions and entrepreneurs in the EA/aligned space. It could matter to individuals who get funding or useful mentorship (the programme has $200k to distribute), but it is not foundational to EA theory or strategy and the scale is modest. For general humanity the post is low-impact: a useful local opportunity for a few projects but not materially important at societal scale.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Missing EA-relevant impact and selection information — EA readers will want to know how this programme decides what is "high impact" and how outcomes are measured. Actionable fixes: state the selection criteria (what you prioritise: cost-effectiveness, neglectedness, tractability, scalability?), give examples of past alumni and concrete outcomes (money raised, projects scaled, impact metrics), and explain what kinds of food-system interventions you consider highest priority. If you can, add a short sentence about how you think the programme’s work compares to the counterfactual (i.e. why funding these teams through this incubator is better than alternatives).

2) Important logistical details are missing and the link is non-HTTPS — the post feels urgent but leaves readers with too many unanswered practical questions. Actionable fixes: include eligibility (who can apply), exact programme dates, estimated time commitment, stipend amount and what it covers, visa/travel support details, whether remote participation is possible, and whether applicants outside certain geographies are eligible. Also update the URL to use https://kickstartingforgood.org or link to the specific application page so readers can click safely.

3) No transparency about funding allocation, timeline, or contact point — readers will want to know how many teams will be funded, typical award sizes, the application review timeline, and who to ask for questions. Actionable fixes: say how many teams will receive part of the $200k (or the typical grant range), give key dates (selection notifications), and provide a contact email or Slack/Discord for questions. Consider adding a one-line note on the funder(s) or governance/oversight for the seed funding to avoid perceived conflicts of interest.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: Targets major, relevant omissions for an EA audience (selection/impact criteria, concrete outcomes, logistics, funding allocation, contact info). These are actionable, would materially increase trust and usefulness, and can mostly be added with concise sentences rather than bloating the post. Not catastrophic errors, but leaving them unaddressed would substantially reduce the post's value to EA readers.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: No significant presence in EA/rationalist circles or the broader public record as of my knowledge cutoff (2024-06). 'PeterSlattery' appears to be either a common personal name or a pseudonymous username with no widely cited publications, talks, or leadership roles in EA; thus very low prominence on both scales.

PostClarity.explanation: The post is concise and easy to understand: it states the programme, target focus (food-system ideas), duration, in-person requirement, stipend coverage, available seed funding, application link and a clear deadline. It could be improved by briefly clarifying eligibility/selection criteria, who is funding it (explicitly), and any application requirements or expected award sizes, but for an announcement it is well-structured and informative.

PostNovelty.explanation: This is primarily an event/program announcement (incubator with seed funding, logistics, and deadline). Such calls for applications and EA‑funded incubators are very common within the EA community, so it offers almost no novel conceptual content for that audience. For the general public it’s slightly more specific/new (a particular program, amount, and Berlin in‑person weeks) but still a routine type of opportunity announcement rather than an original idea.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: This is primarily an informational announcement rather than an argumentative post, so reasoning is simple, clear and internally consistent (hence a high reasoning score). However, empirical evidence about the programme's effectiveness, selection criteria, past outcomes, or how the $200k will be allocated is absent. The post provides a LinkedIn contact and a website link (helpful but limited) and states logistical facts (stipend, in-person weeks, deadline) without supporting data. Overall, the claim that the incubator is seeking applicants and offering funding is credible, but claims about impact or value are weakly supported.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Most of the post’s factual claims are supported by primary/authoritative sources: Kickstarting for Good is a ProVeg-run incubator, the programme is described on the official site as a 15‑week programme with two in‑person weeks in Berlin, travel/accommodation stipends are provided, and the site and press releases state ~$200k total in grants/seed funding for graduating initiatives. The application URL in the post is correct. Two claims are unclear or inconsistent: (1) the exact application deadline — ProVeg’s March 2025 press release and several authoritative reposts list April 30, 2025 (while some secondary reposts and the EA post state May 23, 2025), and I found no ProVeg page that explicitly confirms a May 23 deadline; and (2) the post title’s label “EA Funded” is not substantiated by public grant records I could find (no public EA Funds / Effective Ventures / Open Phil grant page naming Kickstarting for Good). Because the core programme details are well-supported but the deadline and “EA‑funded” label are unverified/conflicting, I rate this as well‑supported overall but with notable uncertainties.
sources: Kickstarting for Good (official site) — kickstartingforgood.org (programme summary showing 15 weeks, two in‑person weeks, stipend, $200,000 total).

ProVeg International press release (11 Mar 2025) — 'ProVeg seeks creative minds to change the food system with Kickstarting For Good Incubator' (states applications close 30 April 2025 and details on funding/prizes).
EA Forum post by PeterSlattery (10 May 2025) — the post being evaluated (claims deadline 23 May 2025 and quotes Sebastian Joy).
Climatebase / job posting & related program pages (listings summarising the 15‑week programme, stipend, $200k funding and show April 30, 2025 deadline in some reposts).
ProVeg Incubator pages / press (background on Kickstarting for Good, Sebastian Joy as founder and programme descriptions).
PPTI / news reposts summarising the programme and prize breakdown (reporting April 30, 2025 deadline and prize amounts).
Sebastian Joy personal site / ProVeg ‘About’ pages (confirming Sebastian Joy’s role and quotes used in press coverage).
